OMEGA 3-6-9 Strawberry: Vegetarian Omega 3, 6, 9 complex
for cardiovascular health provides essential fatty acids that the body cannot
produce on its own. This product helps fight cholestoral and blood pressure
related conditions, while addressing many other health needs. 
PREFADE: Hangover prevention in
Lemon-Lime-Tangerine flavor, PreFade is taken before you drink alcohol so it's
already working when tomorrow comes. We use a natural blend of nutrients
designed to replenish what overindulgence takes away when mixed with plenty of
water. 
RESTERA: All-natural sleep aid that
helps you to relax and get to sleep more easily. We use nature's own relaxation
compounds, including melatonin, herb, and plant derivatives. Ideal for travel,
Restera comes in a vanilla cream flavor.
SPORTFLEX: This product is a glucosamine,
chondroitin, and collagen antioxidant superfruit mix in a delicious blended
fruit flavor. Sportflex provides targeted nutritional support critical to
joints in an antioxidant-rich superfruit juice that also incldes acai and
mangosteen. This product helps to fortify cartilage and connective tissues
stressed by athletic activity or deterioration due to aging, promoting
flexibility and smooth, pain-free movement.
TRIMLITE: All-natural superfruit blend that
helps boost metabolism and burn away fat with no caffeine and no jitters! Helps
reduce appetite and food cravings with a concentrated liquid that absorbs
quickly and completely. Our exclusive energy enhancing formula includes acai
berry, black currant, maca root, elderberry, and cupuacu alongside a full range
of critical nutrients and antioxidants for your body. Trimlite comes in a tangy
berry flavor.

story:
Our Story

After years of designing mental health units for healthcare systems and state facilities, our team recognized the need to move beyond traditional thinking in room design to reduce and eliminate the opportunity for a patient to intentionally harm themselves. While most room elements can be selected to limit opportunities for self-injury, options for door security have been limited and do not provide protection at all portions of a door and its hardware. The development of a comprehensive door monitoring system that could reduce unnecessary client death or injury and limit costly claims settlements was an exciting opportunity. Approximately  1,500 suicides occur annually in US inpatient hospital units, with 75% involving hanging and over 40% of those attempts are by hanging on doors. Just doing some quick math, that's over 400 lives that could be saved with our door monitoring system.

The creation of a reliable operating sensor mechanism was a difficult challenge. To meet the goals of sensitivity, reliability, flexibility and ease of staff operation for both new and retrofit doors, we spent over two years working with our consulting engineers developing and improving a mechanical, electronic, and programming system. The forces on door hinges are surprisingly complex, but we were able to resolve these issues by using multiple sensor points and data management programming. The resulting system has variable sensitivity that allows for the normal use of the doors while notifying staff immediately if a patient attempts to use any part of the door assembly for self-injury.

Overall installed system

Sensor

Open door

Monitor in Normal Status Green

Monitor in Alarm Status Red


How Does it Work?

Unlike other alarm systems that cover only portions of a patient door, the SentinelStop system is the only one available that provides remote monitoring of every part of a patient door to prevent self-injury. It is invisible to the patient, tamper-proof, safe, accurate and dependable. Once installed, SentinelStop provides accurate and instantaneous monitoring. 

In simple terms, the sensor system turns a patient door into a weight scale which will register any increase or decrease in weight from the norm. It will alert staff at the slightest indication of excess weight on a door frame, regardless of where weight is applied: hinge, latch, or the door itself. 

A central monitor displays a floor plan with a visual warning and audio alarm when weight is imposed on any part of the door assembly. An alarm event changes the normal green status bar to red and indicates exactly which door/room requires immediate attention. The alarm cannot be disabled until the cause of the alarm has been attended to.

Sensor connections and monitor showing normal door status

Individual door icon showing an alarm status


Why We Need You

Over the past three years we have developed working prototypes of our sensor system and verified its functionality and signal quality. We want to take our product to the next level. As sensors are now more readily available and much smaller than when we started developing our sensor system, we will work with a well-known sensor manufacturing company to reduce both the size and resulting cost of our system meeting our development goals. 

Your donations will allow us to complete the engineering work for the smaller, more cost effective sensor, refine the computer programs, manufacture and install the sensor into a VA demonstration site to monitor the results prior to a larger-scale production of the sensor units. When you assist us in our goal, you will be helping us save lives.

What Makes SentinelStop Different?

The SentinelStop sensor system is the only product on the market that can provide total door protection. Many products currently on the market can be defeated by the patient. Furthermore, typical top of door sensors are accessible by the patient increasing false alarms. This makes SentinelStop a great tool for mental health caregivers. 

The SentinelStop sensor is designed for either new construction or retrofitting existing door frames. Since the system can detect weight placed on any part of the door, it is not necessary to change existing door hardware or accessories except the hinges.

Our dedication to reducing and eliminating opportunities for suicide at inpatient mental health units is our top priority. A reliable warning system in a patient's room that alerts staff quickly of a potential suicide attempt will allow caregivers to immediately assist the patient, enabling them to receive needed treatment, to heal and return to a normal productive life. The physical safety of the client is our inspiration to continue to forge ahead with our sensor technology. 

Our ground-breaking system was nominated by one of our medical clients for consideration as a top innovative product in the healthcare market. SentinelStop was subsequently awarded a place in HEALTHCARE DESIGN's 2010 Top 10 Platinum Products highlighting the Top 10 designs that displayed a flair for creativity, with usefulness and inventiveness.


Production Plan

We have come a long way since our idea began to take shape and with you, we will be able to move forward in our goal to save lives.


Links

Please visit our website http://www.sentinelstop.com for additional information and follow us on Facebook and Twitter.

Special Thanks:

Leonard Production Services | Video Production

Helen Forster | Voice Over

Eric Steinmates | Door Animations


SentinelStop Team Members

STEPHEN YOUNG 

Stephen Young, inventor of the door sensor system, founded SentinelStop in hopes of creating a comprehensive sensor product that would provide protection at all portions of a door and its hardware for at-risk mental health patients. He is a registered architect with a Masters of Architecture and the owner of Young and Associates Architects, a Minneapolis based architectural firm. His expertise includes the design and development of medical and institutional projects, meeting the healthcare design needs for inpatient mental and behavioral mental health units for over 30 years. Stephen is currently the Principal Architect for the renovation at Miller-Dwan Medical Center inpatient adult behavioral health services unit in Duluth, MN.

LAWRENCE WILZ

Lawrence Wilz is a partner in SentinelStop with responsibilities for finances and IT. He shares the duties for operations, production and contracts with Stephen. He is a registered architect with a Masters of Architecture and a Project Manager for Young & Associates Architects. Prior to this he worked for over fourteen years at a Minneapolis design-build firm attaining the level of Director of Project Architecture. Lawrence is the Project Manager for the renovation for the Miller-Dwan Medical Center inpatient adult behavioral health services unit in Duluth with Young & Associates Architects.  

SUSAN TABOR

Susan Tabor is a psychiatric nurse and hospital administrator. She earned her Bachelor of Science degree in Nursing from the University of Minnesota, Twin Cities campus and her M.B.A. at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, Texas. Prior to her current role as principal of TaborRx, partner in SentinelStop Inc. and Director of the Geriatric Mental Health Service at Ridgeview Medical Center, Susan was Executive Director of Allina Mental Health.


Risks and Challenges

Product development and design is inherently difficult. Bringing a technology product to market has many challenges. We have spent over 3 years developing a functioning prototype that has undergone extensive testing. These test results have led us to a more compact and cost-effective design. All that is left is to synthesize the final design with our development partners, refine our computer programs to include learning software to adapt to each doors swing load and schedule a production prototype run. We will partner with a VA facility to install test units in their mental health unit and work with us to fine-tune the sensor system operations.

  • Engineering 

The initial analysis, prototype, testing and scope of work has already been done. Once we are funded, we will go-ahead with the final engineering, which is scheduled to take approximately four months, then, move into beta unit testing.

  • Manufacturing 

We have a strong relationship with the local manufacturer of our initial prototypes. They are on-board with the tooling requirements and stand ready to incorporate the final engineering. They are a well established firm that has been assisting us throughout each step in our prototyping phase. 

  • Software

The overall sensor software has been written and tested. Our software engineer will write additional programming for rolling averages and include a learning mode to adjust for variables (i.e. door swing). 

 

We hope you will agree that our life saving sensor system is an important development and worth getting into the hands of as many caregivers as possible. We would appreciate both your donation and willingness to share our story with your friends, co-workers and families.

From the entire team our most sincere,

Thank You!

story:
I have had a few sport related injuries... I have torn my ACL, on both back legs now, on separate occasions, I have very little cartilage left in my knees, and I am developing arthritis in the left knee, seriously. I need to have My right leg fixed right away before it gets worse. Once the right leg is healed we will work on correcting the preexisting injury on the left leg. We will donate any unused funds to the A.S.P.C.A.. Thank you for your support, and hope to see you soon!

Love,
Mr. Pink

story:
Therapy that's in touch with your tomorrow.

We are passionate about using technology to improve the quality of life of its users, and as athletes, we know how critical physical therapy is to a better quality of life. Physical therapy and healthcare should be all about the patients, but right now physical therapists have no way of knowing whether patients have completed their exercises, whether it’s been completed correctly, and whether patients are in pain. And that’s why we’ve put aside our basketball rivalry to make physical therapy finally all about YOU.

 

Tiba Health was founded at the Triangle Health Innovation Challenge (THInC) in September 2015, and is a cooperative initiative between students from Duke University and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill who are passionate about improving health outcomes using technological innovations. 

By bridging the gap between tech and healthcare, Tiba Health will improve physical therapy for both the therapist and the patient through a three-way solution:

  • An easy-to-wear Tiba device tracks exercise motion in 3-dimensions

  • A mobile app, linked to the device, provides real-time, corrective feedback to the patient

  • An interface integrated with electronic health records (EHRs) displays collected exercise data and progress to the provider

 

Therapists receive valuable metrics about their patients, while patients receive real-time feedback to improve their therapy experience at home. Tiba will

  • Facilitate patient-provider communication.

  • allow providers and patients to monitor patient biometric data, and for accessible provider control over modifying the exercise regimen based on patient progress.
  • Enhanced personalization of care and patient education.
 

     

    Meet the team

    Risks & Challenges

     

    • 2nd gen FDA approval—We will be obtaining FDA approval for the 2nd generation of our device. This approval process could potentially be long and fairly expensive depending on how the FDA chooses to classify the wearable. The Tiba team plans to consult with experienced FDA attorneys to ensure the process proceeds as smoothly as possible.

    • Institutional Review Board (IRB) approval from Duke Hospitals—To conduct user testing of the wearable device, we will need to acquire movement data to improve the movement analytics models, ensuring we are providing accurate data. Tiba is in touch with physical therapists within the Duke Hospitals system to learn more about conducting user testing, with testing scheduled to begin in spring and summer of 2016.

     

     

    Join us in building therapy that's in touch with tomorrow!

story:
Our Story

My name is Clair Carr and I am a single mom of two. My 20 year old son Robert Carrie was diagnosed 4 years ago with stage 3 kidney failure due to a disease called FSGS (Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis). He has high blood pressure from the kidney failure and is on 6 different medications at this time. He is currently stage 4 and on the waiting list for a kidney transplant. It can take up to 3 - 3 1/2 years to receive a transplant. He is a very smart, caring person. He is planning to return to college where he wants to take courses that will enable him to pursue a career in game design.  I also support my 22 year old daughter Caitlin and her almost 2 year old daughter Madison. Madison had a traumatic birth injury where her shoulder was stuck during birth. She was born with a Brachial Plexis injury that left her unable to use her left arm at all due to the nerves being stretched. She has since had two surgeries, and now has limited use of her arm. She is extremely smart, funny, sweet and determined. She does not let it slow her down and even learned to walk after her second surgery with a big brace on her arm and upper body. I am currently going back to school so that I will be able to get a better job to support my family. While I am in school, I am working part time and having to pay cobra health insurance. I am almost done (graduate February 3rd!). I will still have to pay cobra for several months after I find a job and wait for the benefits to take effect.


The Impact

I hope that it will encourage other single mothers to step out in faith and strive for a better life for them and their children. I have gotten through everything going on in our lives through my faith in God. He is my strength and my sustainer. It was through him that I was led to this website where I can post our story and reach out to others in our time of need. I look forward to the time when I can in turn bless others the way we have been blessed. It will help me to keep the much needed medical coverage my family needs in the coming months.


What We Need & What You Get

Our cobra payments are over a thousand a month. The money we receive from the campaign will help to pay the cost of this and also for co-pays for doctor visits, prescriptions, etc. He will also be starting on dialysis soon and it will help with the copays. It will greatly help my children and grandchild to see the incredible kind and generous people who are willing to lend a helping hand to others. You will receive our heartfelt thanks and the satisfaction of knowing you helped a young man and his family during a very difficult time in his life. I hope it will plant seeds in my children and grandchild to pay it forward throughout their lifetime.


Other Ways You Can Help

 Please send this to your Facebook friends, friends, colleagues, family to pass along and get the word out. If you can't donate, please take a moment to pray or send her your positive energy. Anything will help.

story:
Children Of War Foundation (C.O.W.F.) will be operating on children that need life altering and  sub specialized surgeries during their mission in Jordan at the King Hussein Hospital.  These operations are some of the most complex and life threatening conditions. The reality of the matter is that these children would not get the operations without our sub specialized surgeons.  The financial burden of trying to bring these children to the United States for treatment would have cost many millions of dollars to provide the care.  In an effort to contain costs, and provide the most meaningful impact, we proceeded with securing the hospital and the surgeons, in order to provide care in Jordan. 

 

Children of War Foundation is a non-profit 501(c) 3 entity that provides surgical and medical treatment to children throughout the world, and here in the United States.  We are a unique organization in that none of our members receive any form of financial compensation.  

  

The money needed is to help cover the cost of medical equipment, some logistical expenses for the doctors that will be operating and donating their time. It will also cover some basic legal and logistical fees for making this mission happen and the opportunity to ensure that we can operate on as many kids as possible.

 If you would like to get more detailed information on the children we will be operating on, the mission or how you can get involved, please contact us at info@cowf.org

 

We are fortunate enough to have the following members that will be embarking on the mission, which will start June 1st.   

 Dr. MarkUrata, Chief of Plastic Surgery at University of Southern California (USC), Division Head at Children’s Hospital Los Angeles

Dr Jeffrey Hammoudeh, Director Jaw Deformities Center, USC Plastic Surgery, Children’s Hospital Los Angeles

Dr. Andrew Ordon, Plastic Surgeon, Doctors Show

Dr. Andy Chang, Pediatric Urologists, USC, Children’s Hospital Los Angeles

Dr. Andrea Panossian, Director of Vascular Anomalies, Children’s Hospital Los Angeles

Dr. Kami Parsa, Occulo Plastics, Rox Surgery

Luis Olivares, Chief Operating Room Technician

Janet Dotson. Sr. Media Producer & Public Information Officer, Children’s Hospital Los Angeles

Amel Najjar, Executive Director

Hany Haddad, COWF Communications & Outreach Director

 

 

We thank you for your contribution and your time!

COWF TEAM

www.cowf.org

https://www.facebook.com/childrenofwarfoundation

http://www.youtube.com/childrenofwar

story: ---

Welcome to 

Gypsy Tonic formula No. 29!


   Embrace Life, Freedom, Dreams and Love.

Awaken to New Possibilities.

 Experience the Mystery of Gypsy Tonic and 

Invigorate your Spirit. 




MINI GYPSY Gift Bag

Gypsy Tonic 29/Tote-bag/T-shirt (Thank you card & sticker not pictured)


What is this Amazing "Gypsy Tonic" you speak of?



  Gypsy Tonic is a Revolutionary Artisan supplement that produces a unique kind of experience when compared to other drinks on the market. It's a product that is extremely healthy, promotes balance, uses only premium ingredients and provides something other than a caffeine buzz to energize. It’s packed full of Amazing components found all around the world: from exotic islands to deep jungles, Himalayan mountains, and desert flat-lands. 

         

We have taken the concept, class, and style of vintage tonics from the late 1800's and early 1900's and have added a modern day spin with ancient ingredients.

  The Gypsy Tonic recipe is very intentional and carefully formulated to create an overall balanced experience. Every ingredient is there for a reason — you take one out and it’s just not the same. It was our goal from the beginning to not cut any corners from conception to production. There are generous amounts of all the finest ingredients in each bottle to ensure you get plenty of the good stuff.



The lineup of Gypsy Tonic ingredients:



     All natural ingredients in their purist form. No artificial flavors, nothing Genetically Modified (Non-GMO), and no preservatives. Only the best and finest ingredients for your enjoyment!


                       


Some of the Amazing Benefits & Health properties of Gypsy Tonic:

  Gypsy Tonic is truly one of a kind. There is no one type of experience while enjoying it. Its effects are as unique as you are and benefit everyone differently. We like to say it has an individualized energy response that is specially tailored to your body! Keep reading to learn more about the amazing components that make up Gypsy Tonic! 


SuperFoods?

Superfoods are antioxidant-rich and nutrient-dense powerhouse foods that pack more of a punch than your average food item ingredient.


Ayurvedic Herbs?

Ayurveda is a holistic healing school of thought developed in India thousands of years ago. Part of the teachings include the use of specific herbs to bring the body back into balance. Gypsy Tonic uses two elements from Ayurveda.


What else?

 Gypsy Tonic is extremely high in antioxidants and replenishes minerals and electrolytes. 


Why isn't Gypsy Tonic Certified Organic?

     This was a tough challenge for us from the beginning because of how important it is for us to deliver the best quality product possible. In order to be certified organic 95% of the ingredients have to be organic. Shilajit doesn’t come in an organic option because it is a mineral pitch and cannot be certified organic. The same goes for the Ionic Sea Minerals which also do not come in an organic certifiable form. Though they aren’t certified organic, our Shilajit, Bacopa, Ginseng and Ionic Sea Minerals are all organically harvested and very clean ingredients. At Bohemian Revolution Beverage Co. we value integrity. This means your health and well-being always come first! In the future if we can find an organic substitute that is as good, or better, than a particular ingredient we are currently using we will definitely make the change! 



So what does it taste like?


  Gypsy Tonic has a smooth mellow chocolaty flavor with a hint of almond. Cacao (unprocessed cocoa powder) is the main ingredient in this supplement, first for its health properties, and secondly for its taste. Although there is a lot of cacao in it, Gypsy Tonic does not have an overbearing chocolate taste. And though it is not carbonated, it manages to have a tiny bit of zing in it. When combined with the other exotic ingredients, the flavor takes on a uniqueness that has layers of mystery embedded in its flavor profile.

Even if you’re not a Chocolate lover, we recommend giving Gypsy Tonic a whirl. You'll probably enjoy the way you feel when drinking this unique supplement. Enjoy during the special moments of life or for everyday use!




The Story...

  Hello, friends, fellow bohemians and IndieGoGo family! My name is Brandon Johnson, at heart I am an artist and gravitate towards playing music, dancing and writing, but truly enjoy all forms of the creative process. I also enjoy traveling, festivals, and adventures of all sorts. I always seem to be on the go and I am excited to share with you my secret of how I keep going and keep creative.

        

Gypsy Tonic has been my passion for the last few years and I started making this concoction in my house as a substitute to other forms of energy enhancing drinks. I noticed it created a different, more subtle, more controlled form of energy and focus as well as replenishing and boosting my nutrient levels without over-stimulating – generating a productive, creative state of mind while promoting an overall feel good vibe. 

(Plus I tend to be a bit on the caffeine sensitive side, so it was important to find something that didn't give me a case of the jitters.)


  Awhile back one of my best friends had introduced me to some new and exciting ingredients that got me exploring a whole new area of health and wellness. Using some of these new ingredients from the Ayurvedic and Peruvian modalities, and adding some of my other tried and true ingredients I use when looking for a boost, I developed and fine tuned the first batch of Gypsy Tonic.


  It is now my go to drink whenever I am looking to get a buzz, focus on a project, add an extra kick to a night out (or recover from a night out), or simply bring my spirits up when I'm having one of those "off" days. Sometimes I'll just drink some to see what happens. And, of course, I still whip up a batch of Gypsy Tonic whenever I am feeling like I could use a creative boost.

I started sharing my recipe with friends and family and got some great responses and some great feedback, which led to the idea of being able to share it with Everyone!

Which brings us to IndieGoGo...

It all starts here, and it starts with you! 


You're Invited to 

Be part of the Revolution!


     We are excited to invite you to be a part of this unique journey with the Bohemian Revolution Beverage Co. family. This groundbreaking supplementary beverage won't be possible without your help. Everything is in place and ready to go. Now it's time to make it happen. 


     We are asking for your donations to fund the start-up phase of Bohemian Revolution Beverage Co. and to breathe life into this project.


The Plan :


  The initial start-up will be a grass roots style beginning based in Southern California, touring the Farmers Market circuit as well as music festivals, art and craft fairs and anywhere their is an artistic uprising.

  We will start with a touring Vendor booth, while also working around the clock opening accounts with locally owned niche shops and providing self distribution. As the business grows, we will shift to 3rd party distribution services until Gypsy Tonic makes it to Your local marketplace.





     We aren't asking for something for nothing. We have lots of really cool Bohemian Revolution Beverage Co. gear to give back: Tote bags, T-shirts, stickers, prints and, to show our thanks that you were with us from the beginning and supported us at our earliest stages, first dibs on the very first batch of Gypsy Tonic Formula No. 29!

Tote-Bag   

(Cotton Tote-bag, Navy Blue, 15" x 16")

T-Shirt

(Premium Soft T-shirt. Crew-neck or V-neck.) 
 

Prices change. Check the Perks column for up to date pricing.





It's More than a Supplement, 

It's a Movement!



Your Journey is Our Mission.


     Our Mission is to provide you with the energy and clarity to shake off the blindfolds of worldly clutter and to reconnect you to what matters most. Your life purpose is important to us, and we want to help you in sustaining your drive and focus for you to follow your dreams into completion, turning your creative thoughts into reality. 




Reconnect to the simplicity and purity of life. 


     Gypsy Tonic embodies the spirit of living a life that is fully extended, working towards dreams, connecting with people, invoking self awareness, transcending any kind of drone mentality or limiting thought process, and speaking boldly from the heart. We believe in contributing to the world in a positive way, and understand the importance of the journey and those we meet along the roads we travel. We are here to support you on your journey with our tonics and elixirs.


Your Revolution is Here and Now!

Be Truly Free...




Other ways to Help out.


"I'm really into this Campaign, but I don't have money to Contribute. Is there anything else I can do?"

Even a $5 contribution helps, and is quick and easy.

If you can stretch even a little and make a donation you can be part of this journey with us, and we strongly believe that giving has a way of coming back in great ways.

If you truly can't make a donation there are other ways to contribute. Help spread the word! A good place to start is family, friends, and people who you think would be interested in the uniqueness of this project. We need your help! Take it to the streets. Make some noise for Gypsy Tonic and the Bohemian Revolution Beverage Co.


If you do donate to the cause, you can multiply your investment by sharing these links with any and all people who you think would enjoy this fun and meaningful campaign and spreading the word to make sure this project is a success. If we do reach our goal then we get to look into stretch rewards for you as well!


Final Thoughts


  Thank you for checking out our campaign! We would really love to have you on board and help us create a Supplement so awesome and pure that it transcends from beverage into a communal work of art. Made by artists for artists and free spirits alike. For the bohemian at heart. Drink when you want to ignite the fire of the spirit, embrace life and unlock a world of possibilities!

We are excited for you to be a part of this movement and the Bohemian Revolution Beverage Co. Family!


Sincerely and with much Love,

~Brandon Lee Johnson, and the Bohemian Revolution Beverage Co. Team!

story:
UPDATES:

***3 Days Left!  Help us reach our first goal of $2500.  $2500 will enable us to launch a scholarship fund, support our Ambassador program and contribute to CAA's health/wellness program.

***Thank you for joining us in our 5k on Saturday, October 26th.  We really appreciate your early support, your contributions and your steps towards A Healthy Billion Challenge.

A Healthy Billion is a Startup Ironman

Three companies with three big goals for 2013/2014 come together with 1 major focus:  Building a community dedicated to working together to improve everyday health...by the billions.

The following projects are the 'swim, bike and run' of what we are calling a startup ironman:

  • "The Swim" : College of Adaptive Arts, a non-profit building an innovative college for adults with disabilities - this year we need to find a permanent home for the college.  We are also working on building a professional health & wellness department.
  • "The Bike" :  Vidapost, building a care coordination platform focused on simplifying the management of everyday care while continuously focusing on improving everyday health - this year our goal is to launch our first membership program, build and test our communication platform and complete our first healthy billion challenge:  1 billion steps.
  • "The Run" : BuddiesInACTION, specializing in professional health & wellness programs for teens and adults with disabilities.  - this year we are working on building a scholarship fund, offering workshops to staff and instructors on how to implement the ACTION philosophy to build inclusive wellness programs, and expanding to other cities and locations via our headquarters and affiliate programs.

A Healthy Billion is a Personal Commitment

While each company has their own "event" (and projects), their own mission and their own personal team, Jen Pleimann, has signed up for the full startup Ironman.  She is the co-chair of the College of Adaptive Arts, the founder of Vidapost and the founder of BuddiesInACTION.

Typically, this time of year Jen can be found riding 100 miles from Carmel to Hearst Castle and leading TeamFITBuddies in the Audi Best Buddies' Challenge but this year she has embarked on a new challenge and is asking for your support as she pursues her passion and embarks on a new professional journey.

A little about Jen:

Current SF resident, originally from the midwest (St. Louis) with a dose of the east coast (Connecticut), south (South Carolina) and southwest (Oklahoma).  Jen is a University of Wisconsin-Madison grad with a BS in Psychology and a work background encompassing many health related fields and settings including:  behavioral therapist (for autism); physical therapy assistant; home health aide; and personal trainer.

She is a proud XXinHealth-er who has stepped away from providing care to solving everyday care problems.  She does not have a MBA, she has MORE.  She is a single member founder (with a great team), an outside-the-box thinker, and an optimistic, glass is always half full kind of thinker.  And yes, she has undertaken three different endeavors but all with one main focus.

You can typically find Jen in workout attire with her laptop in hand (or at least nearby) and personal training a FIT in Los Altos a couple days a week.  When not working on 1 of her 3 initiatives, she enjoys working out (de-stressing), spending time with friends, supporting her boyfriend's sports addiction or singing at the top of her lungs on her commute down 280.  Although 3,000 miles away, Jen remains extremely close to her family and in fact, her sister, Tracy Richardson, is involved with both BuddiesInACTION and Vidapost.

A Message from Jen - Why this is so important to me:

It has been my everyday experiences in a variety of professional settings (homes, clinics, gyms, schools) that has led me to my current endeavors.  For me, it is not about "what" I am working on or "how" I am going to solve the problems (although of course extremely important) but what keeps me going is WHY I am doing what I am doing:

  • Because I worked in the homes of individuals with chronic conditions and witnessed the day in, day out struggles of everyday caregiving and understand the disconnect between everyday care and medical care from both a professional and patient/caregiver perspective.
  • Because I have witnessed the life changing effects of professional health & wellness programs for individuals with disabilities
  • Because I have watched adults with disabilities who were non-verbal, shy and disconnected from society "find their purpose" and become contributing citizens by taking college courses that cater to their strengths and abilities.

A healthy billion is a personal commitment and a professional endeavor that I am calling a startup ironman.  And although I have never completed an actual Ironman, I have witnessed many and been a part of the training and I am well aware that it is an event that takes a village to complete:  participants, coaches, volunteers and so on.  Most importantly it takes community support to help cheer participants through each event and across the finish line.  The startup ironman will require the same village.

A Healthy Billion is a Community Event

As mentioned, the main focus of A Healthy Billion is to build a community (that includes YOU) to work together to improve health...by the billions.  We are asking for your support in the crazy ironman startup because we know that with your help, together we can cross the finish line and make a difference...by the billions.  Here's how you can help:

  • Make a donation (seriously, any amount helps): 20% goes to CAA, 40% to BuddiesInACTION, 40% to Vidapost.  
  • Move with us:  Swim, Bike, Run, Walk and help us reach a billion steps (you can pledge $35 and we will email you a promo code or sign up directly at www.vidapost.com).  Please note we have extended the challenge past Aug. 31st and will continue until we reach 1 Billion; You may register as a 'healthy' patient if you are not a caregiver, provider and do not have a chronic condition.  Every step earns points towards health & wellness services for our Ambassadors who are adults with disabilities.
  • Spread the word:  Share our campaign and initiatives.  Our number 1 goal is to build our community so help us spread the word.


What We Need & What You Get

Most of the contribution levels are actual prices for some of our programs and services.  While we do have some tangible 'perks' (t-shirts, water bottles, etc) your contributions will go towards paying for a membership for yourself, sponsoring a friend, family or organization, or sponsoring the launch of an actual program or even a city launch!  Below is the distribution of funding and what we hope to accomplish with your contributions:

  • CAA (20%):  We hope to expand our health & wellness department within CAA to offer more professional classes.  This year they also hope to establish an official college campus for our students and solidify 500K in funding.
  • BuddiesInACTION (40%):  The funds raised will go towards establishing a scholarship fund and if you sponsor an affiliate program and/or headquarters you will have the option to specify the area you would like to see the program launched.
  • Vidapost (40%):  Funds raised will support A Healthy Billion Challenge and support our Ambassadors who are individuals with intellectual disabilities leading the challenge by both participating and sending encouraging messages to their teammates.

Please note that contributions are not tax deductive.  If you would like to contribute directly to the college of adaptive arts you may make a tax deductible donation with them.  

As mentioned, the number one goal is building our community and understanding that we all have a role to play.  We have set up our 'perks' a little bit differently than most campaigns as we want you to be an active part of our network, building and creating with us as well as receiving.

More about the 3 Projects:

1) College of Adaptive Arts (CAA):  Building an innovative college for adults with disabilities, specializing in the arts. 

To date, programs and state funding for individuals with disabilities ends at the age of 22. Services are limited and opportunities are sparse.  The CAA's goal is to establish a college campus so they can continue growing the programs and services that enable adults with disabilities to be contributing members of society.

Follow CAA:  Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn

Watch the video to learn more about CAA.  Courtesy of Gabrielle Makower.


2) BuddiesInACTION:  Improving the health & wellness of individuals with intellectual disabilities.  

Erin Hopfinger, a fellow St. Joe Angel, recently partnered with Jen to begin growing and expanding BuddiesInACTION.  Our goal is to expand the FITBuddies' program Jen started at FIT via our affiliate program to other gyms and organizations.  We offer training and workshops for teachers, trainers and wellness instructors on how to implement the ACTION philosophy in any type of health & wellness program.  We will be launching headquarters in various cities to to establish comprehensive wellness programs and build a wider community to address all the health & wellness needs of an individual.

A Special Congrats to Red Dot Fitness, one of our initial affiliates, on launching their BuddiesInACTION program in San Jose this fall!!

Follow BuddiesInACTION:  Facebook, Twitter

The video below shows our first program FITBuddies, offered at FIT in Los Altos, CA

3) Vidapost:  Simplifying everyday care, improving everyday health.

At Vidapost we believe every single one of us has a role to play as a provider, as a caregiver and as a patient and that by working together, in a systematic way, we can make vast changes to improve everyday care.  We are building a care coordination platform focused on simplifying the management of everyday care with a continued focus on improving everyday health.  Today care coordination is not only scattered and disconnected but it is also only viewed as a medical problem (ie.  only includes doctors, nurses, specialist, etc).  At Vidapost, our goal is to connect the everyday providers and caregivers in a simplified way and enable the medical care team to connect to the information pertinent to their point of care.  

Follow Vidapost:  Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest


Thank you in advance for you support!  If you would like to follow Jen's personal journey, ongoing updates can be found at www.ahealthybillion.com.

Typically, this time of year Jen can be found riding 100 miles from Carmel to Hearst Castle and leading TeamFITBuddies in the Audi Best Buddies' Challenge but this year she has embarked on a new challenge and is asking for your support as she pursues her passion and embarks on a new professional journey.

A little about Jen:
Current SF resident, originally from the midwest (St. Louis) with a dose of the east coast (Connecticut), south (South Carolina) and southwest (Oklahoma).  Jen is a University of Wisconsin-Madison grad with a BS in Psychology and a work background encompassing many health related fields and settings including:  behavioral therapist (for autism); physical therapy assistant; home health aide; and personal trainer.
She is a proud XXinHealth-er who has stepped away from providing care to solving everyday care problems.  She does not have a MBA, she has MORE.  She is a single member founder (with a great team), an outside-the-box thinker, and an optimistic, glass is always half full kind of thinker.  And yes, she has undertaken three different endeavors but all with one main focus.
You can typically find Jen in workout attire with her laptop in hand (or at least nearby) and personal training a FIT in Los Altos a couple days a week.  When not working on 1 of her 3 initiatives, she enjoys working out (de-stressing), spending time with friends, supporting her boyfriend's sports addiction or singing at the top of her lungs on her commute down 280.  Although 3,000 miles away, Jen remains extremely close to her family and in fact, her sister, Tracy Richardson, is involved with both BuddiesInACTION and Vidapost.
A Message from Jen - Why this is so important to me:
It has been my everyday experiences in a variety of professional settings (homes, clinics, gyms, schools) that has led me to my current endeavors.  For me, it is not about "what" I am working on or "how" I am going to solve the problems (although of course extremely important) but what keeps me going is WHY I am doing what I am doing:

Because I worked in the homes of individuals with chronic conditions and witnessed the day in, day out struggles of everyday caregiving and understand the disconnect between everyday care and medical care from both a professional and patient/caregiver perspective.
Because I have witnessed the life changing effects of professional health & wellness programs for individuals with disabilities
Because I have watched adults with disabilities who were non-verbal, shy and disconnected from society "find their purpose" and become contributing citizens by taking college courses that cater to their strengths and abilities.


A healthy billion is a personal commitment and a professional endeavor that I am calling a startup ironman.  And although I have never completed an actual Ironman, I have witnessed many and been a part of the training and I am well aware that it is an event that takes a village to complete:  participants, coaches, volunteers and so on.  Most importantly it takes community support to help cheer participants through each event and across the finish line.  The startup ironman will require the same village.
A Healthy Billion is a Community Event
As mentioned, the main focus of A Healthy Billion is to build a community (that includes YOU) to work together to improve health...by the billions.  We are asking for your support in the crazy ironman startup because we know that with your help, together we can cross the finish line and make a difference...by the billions.  Here's how you can help:


Make a donation (seriously, any amount helps): 20% goes to CAA, 40% to BuddiesInACTION, 40% to Vidapost.  

Move with us:  Swim, Bike, Run, Walk and help us reach a billion steps (you can pledge $35 and we will email you a promo code or sign up directly at www.vidapost.com).  Please note we have extended the challenge past Aug. 31st and will continue until we reach 1 Billion; You may register as a 'healthy' patient if you are not a caregiver, provider and do not have a chronic condition.  Every step earns points towards health & wellness services for our Ambassadors who are adults with disabilities.

Spread the word:  Share our campaign and initiatives.  Our number 1 goal is to build our community so help us spread the word.




What We Need & What You Get
Most of the contribution levels are actual prices for some of our programs and services.  While we do have some tangible 'perks' (t-shirts, water bottles, etc) your contributions will go towards paying for a membership for yourself, sponsoring a friend, family or organization, or sponsoring the launch of an actual program or even a city launch!  Below is the distribution of funding and what we hope to accomplish with your contributions:


CAA (20%):  We hope to expand our health & wellness department within CAA to offer more professional classes.  This year they also hope to establish an official college campus for our students and solidify 500K in funding.

BuddiesInACTION (40%):  The funds raised will go towards establishing a scholarship fund and if you sponsor an affiliate program and/or headquarters you will have the option to specify the area you would like to see the program launched.

Vidapost (40%):  Funds raised will support A Healthy Billion Challenge and support our Ambassadors who are individuals with intellectual disabilities leading the challenge by both participating and sending encouraging messages to their teammates.

Please note that contributions are not tax deductive.  If you would like to contribute directly to the college of adaptive arts you may make a tax deductible donation with them.  
As mentioned, the number one goal is building our community and understanding that we all have a role to play.  We have set up our 'perks' a little bit differently than most campaigns as we want you to be an active part of our network, building and creating with us as well as receiving.


More about the 3 Projects:
1) College of Adaptive Arts (CAA):  Building an innovative college for adults with disabilities, specializing in the arts. 
To date, programs and state funding for individuals with disabilities ends at the age of 22. Services are limited and opportunities are sparse.  The CAA's goal is to establish a college campus so they can continue growing the programs and services that enable adults with disabilities to be contributing members of society.
Follow CAA:  Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn
Watch the video to learn more about CAA.  Courtesy of Gabrielle Makower.

2) BuddiesInACTION:  Improving the health & wellness of individuals with intellectual disabilities.  
Erin Hopfinger, a fellow St. Joe Angel, recently partnered with Jen to begin growing and expanding BuddiesInACTION.  Our goal is to expand the FITBuddies' program Jen started at FIT via our affiliate program to other gyms and organizations.  We offer training and workshops for teachers, trainers and wellness instructors on how to implement the ACTION philosophy in any type of health & wellness program.  We will be launching headquarters in various cities to to establish comprehensive wellness programs and build a wider community to address all the health & wellness needs of an individual.
A Special Congrats to Red Dot Fitness, one of our initial affiliates, on launching their BuddiesInACTION program in San Jose this fall!!
Follow BuddiesInACTION:  Facebook, Twitter
The video below shows our first program FITBuddies, offered at FIT in Los Altos, CA

3) Vidapost:  Simplifying everyday care, improving everyday health.
At Vidapost we believe every single one of us has a role to play as a provider, as a caregiver and as a patient and that by working together, in a systematic way, we can make vast changes to improve everyday care.  We are building a care coordination platform focused on simplifying the management of everyday care with a continued focus on improving everyday health.  Today care coordination is not only scattered and disconnected but it is also only viewed as a medical problem (ie.  only includes doctors, nurses, specialist, etc).  At Vidapost, our goal is to connect the everyday providers and caregivers in a simplified way and enable the medical care team to connect to the information pertinent to their point of care.  
Follow Vidapost:  Facebook, Twitter, Pinterest







Thank you in advance for you support!  If you would like to follow Jen's personal journey, ongoing updates can be found at www.ahealthybillion.com.

story:
My daughter Yemaya lives with both Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) and Fibromyalgia (Fibro). At 32 yrs old she was diagnosed with RA and 6 months later diagnosed with Fibromyalgia. These diseases have slowed her down tremendously.  RA is an auto-immune disease that attacks the body’s tissues and linings of joints causing chronic pain, weakness, and inflammation. As it progresses it can cause severe disability, permanent joint and organ damage.  Fibromyalgia syndrome is a long-term condition which causes pain all over the body more specifically, in the neck, shoulders, back, hips, arms, and legs.  It is difficult and extremely painful for her to do daily activities. I never thought I would see her in a wheelchair or using a walker because she has always been so active and on the go.

Yemaya was a full-time student until the chronic pain got so unbearable that she had to drop the one class she needed to graduate.  She was a proud homeowner in Washington, D.C. until 3 months ago. She had to temporarily move in with family so they could help take care of her due to her debilitating illness.  As her Father it is difficult to watch her in so much pain.  I want to make it all go away but unfortunately I can’t.  There are times when I want to hug her and tell her everything will be okay but her chronic pain is so severe at times I can’t even touch her.  So I’ve decided to focus on getting her better care by reaching out for help because her needs are greater than our means. Whether we meet our funding goal or not, all donations raised from this fundraiser will go towards offsetting her current medical and living expenses. 

Due to her increasingly progressive pain she was admitted to George Washington Hospital and referred to a Spine/Pain Clinic after being discharged from the hospital. The pain clinic recommended she get a procedure called Intravenous Lidocaine Infusion which was supposed to reduce her pain caused by Fibromyalgia significantly, but it was declined yet again because the insurance deemed it experimental.  This type of treatment can average $250.00 per hour, in addition to our out of pocket expenses which include alternative medicine, acupuncture, acupressure, magnetic therapy, water therapy, and holistic care the cost add up quickly.

Most recently we were encouraged to seek additional care through Johns Hopkins second opinion program.  Johns Hopkins Hospital is rated the number one in the nation in Rheumatology but they would not take her insurance either.  An average cost of an initial consult appointment is around $600.  Additionally, she would need a few follow up appointments to review lab work, prescribe medication, and monitor her results.

Employment is farfetched due to her current condition yet when she applied for Medicaid and Social Security Disability Insurance (SSDI) she was denied and provided substandard state insurance that doesn’t cover the medication and procedures needed to manage her pain.  Her doctors are running out of viable options because the medication and procedures they prescribe/recommend are being denied by her insurance.  Out of desperation she applied for private insurance and was also declined for pre-existing conditions.  Thereafter we tried to apply for insurance using the Affordable Care Act website but was not successful either.

Your contributions to her medical and living expenses will help her regain her health, receive the best care at Johns Hopkins Hospital, pay for medication, prevent foreclosure on her home, and complete her final class needed to graduate.  We understand that everyone is not in a position to donate but spreading the word to family and friends would help tremendously.  By helping Yemaya on her road to recovery you will receive a gift as a token of our appreciation.  Also, don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tool… every click counts! We thank you in advance for your support, donations and prayers to help Yemaya Fight Back against Fibromyalgia and Rheumatoid Arthritis.


Minimum/Average cost needed for medical and living expenses

·  Johns Hopkins Second Opinion Program ($5100)

·  Holistic Care ($1000)

·  Prevent foreclosure ($6440).

·  Re-enroll for final class needed to graduate ($7600)

http://www.humira.com/ra/default.aspx
http://www.hopkinsmedicine.org/rheumatology/index.html
http://cityacupuncturecircle.com/
http://www.getwell-rehab.com/cms/
http://www.umuc.edu

story:
UPDATE: This weekend, the very generous and thoughtful members of the Charleston Argentine Tango Society held a fundraiser for Christy and raised just over $4,000! So tack that on in addition to what we've raised here. The news nearly brought Christy to tears when I Skyped with her the next day. Thank you so much to those generous donors who contributed and all of the support you all have given to her. I know she's looking forward to the day she can get back on that dance floor! Thank you to everyone else who has donated directly to this site as well. If I don't know you already, I hope to meet you some day, you all seem like extraordinary people and I'm glad Christy has you in her life. 

Christy is the strongest woman I know. I’m biased, because she’s my mom. But, she has taken some of the most difficult of life’s challenges all in the last few years, from divorce, the loss of her mother, the loss of pets, the loss of work, and a diagnosis of ovarian cancer. She has undergone several rounds of chemo over the past 2 years as well as a full hysterectomy. On August 7th of last year she underwent a drastic and incredibly invasive surgery, designed to seek out and remove any and all cancer throughout her abdominal region. This was one of the most stressful and trying days of my life as I waited to hear the outcome of the surgery. It’s a day I will never forget. Late that night the surgeon called and updated me on the surgery. It was much more extensive than we ever thought, removing the lining of her abdomen, her spleen, her gallbladder, parts of her intestine, and parts of her diaphragm. She was unable to speak for several days and remained in the ICU for 2 weeks. Seeing her in such pain was heart-wrenching. For a woman who was so active before the diagnosis, now unable to walk more than a lap around the nurses’ station, we wondered if we had made the right decision. The hardest part was when she would take her walks into the ICU where she had once laid unconscious for so long. At times it brought us both to tears simply being in that hall but she insisted on walking through it. There were times when patient rooms would suddenly go empty-- people less fortunate than she. I struggled to not break down into tears, telling myself that I was lucky because my mom made it out of the ICU alive. She improved slowly and eventually, tube after tube was removed, all of her staples were taken out of her abdomen, and her walks became longer. She stayed one month longer due to an infection (C. difficile) that occurred just days before she was scheduled to be discharged. If you can imagine an extensive abdominal surgery followed by incessant vomiting you can imagine the pain and the toll this would take you through physically and emotionally.

 

It’s been nearly a year since the surgery. Her life was moving in a positive direction with the support of friends, a compassionate Dragon Boat group, a part-time job, and no sign of cancer. Although cancer loomed in her mind every day and much of her time has been spent researching cancer and doing everything she could to keep the it at bay, her outlook seemed to be a little brighter especially the last few months.  Then we received the news that her CA-125 (a biomarker for ovarian cancer) had risen to 41. Not terribly high but a jump high enough that we knew that our greatest fear was a strong possibility. This week we learned that indeed, the cancer is back. Her PET scan showed activity in areas around her liver, on her intestines, her bladder, and as high up as her clavicle.

 

I need my mom. I want her to live as long as possible. I want her to see me graduate. I want her to be here when my husband and I have kids. I need her.

 

My mom is incredibly independent and has made selfless sacrifices throughout her life to make sure my brother and I could have the lives that we have had. She has always put herself after others and never asks for help, even when she desperately needs it. Now is one of those times which is why I am asking for her. With your contribution she can continue to get treatment and can continue to pay her bills during the time that she cannot work, She has been receiving help from her ex-husband, my father to pay for medical insurance and has been unable to work consistently for years now due to chemotherapy treatments that not only interfere with a working schedule, but hinders her from being hired. Sadly, companies don’t like to hire people who have cancer because they can’t be sure how long they will be around.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

The goal for our fundraising is $20,000. This will help pay for her next treatment and would go towards the many medical bills that have built up over the past few years, as well as other treatments she may need now or in the future such as chemotherapy.

 

In return for your generosity I would like to personally make you something. At one point in my life I painted murals for a small studio in Charleston, SC and since have continued art as a hobby. I primarily do oil paintings, pen and ink drawings, and jewelry making. In the photos section there are examples of some of my work. Subject matter varies in my paintings and drawings and jewelry is typically made with combinations of metal and stones. Being a student, my studies have kept me fairly busy and away from the arts but I always have several projects going on. I hope to truly show you my gratitude through the work that I create for you. For more detail see the “perks” section and examples uploaded into the “photos” section.

 

The Impact

 

With your contribution my mom will be able to get the treatment she needs to continue living. You will be giving the gift of hope and life. You will be giving my brother and I the gift of more time with our mom. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

If you are unable to contribute, please consider helping by sharing our campaign. We can use all of the help we can get!

story:
Our Story

My wife and I were blessed to have our second child, a boy, on October 31st, 2011.  Unfortunately, he was in the NIC Unit for 42 days with an infection that included high fevers and loss of weight but he is now home with us getting better each day, along with a very large medical bill.  During this time I began having very painful health problems which I ignored until the pain was unbearable. I was diagnosed with benign prostatic hyperplasia.  Although the doctor does not think it is cancerous he has advised me that if I do not get the surgery, Trans-Urethral Resection of the Prostate, there is eventually a possibility of cancer of the prostrate.  I have seen three specialists in the Sacramento area and all have given me the same diagnosis.  Sounds very simple except for the cost of the surgery and the mounting medical bills we have for our son.  Thank you for reading my story.

 

What We Need

I have health insurance, unlike some Americans, but my deductible is $7,500 and a 20% co-payment which is out of reach for us.  We do not have savings nor do we have credit cards.  Because this is not an emergency surgery, I need to pay the surgeon my deductible up front before they will do the surgery.  Thank you for any amount of money that you can donate towards my surgery.

 

My Promise

I will pay forward to other family's health needs.  As I told the doctors, I could make long term payments on the surgery, but none will take long term payments, so instead I can make long term payments toward other's health needs through this program.

story:
LETTER FROM HER PARENTS

 

http://www.tijanaognjanovic.com/index-eng.html

Our daughter Tijana Ognjanovic, aged 8, urgently needs help for treatment abroad. Having in mind really serious health condition of the sick girl, who has been diagnosed with restrictive cardiomyopathy, medical council has suggested the transplatiton to be performed as soon as possible.

Having in mind that this kind of operation is not performed in our country, and Republic Institute for health insurance does not cover costs for operation and postoperative treatment of this kind of disease, left on our own, we initiated action for help to Tijana to get a new heart. For relatively short time with help of people of good will who have supported this humanitarian action, we have collected 200.000 EUR for heart transplatation and postoperative treatment in Vienna.

In January this year, we went to Vienna, to AKH clinic, where after detailed analysis they have informed us that clinic is not capable to put Tijana on waiting list and perform heart transplatation, because of complications which have appeared by the end of December 2012. (kidney failure) and very rare form of restrictive cardiomyopathy from which Tijana suffers. As Tijana has been classified in third risk group (there are three groups), they gave her only 2% chance to survive operation in their centre (we have enclosed conclusion of transplantation team from AKH clinic).

Faced with this facts and not wishing to give up, we were forced to find a clinic which has experience with this rare kind of restrictive cardiomyopathy and which would accept Tijana as high risk patient. We have contacted many cardiologists in the country and abroad and we have received data that clinics in America have most experience with this kind of cardiomyopathy, from which the child clinic in Houston has especially stood out. We have contacted them and got answer that in relatively short period we can get heart, but this kind of operation costs 1.015.000,00 $. (Here you can find enclosed breakdown of estimated charges.)

Having in mind report of Tijana’s cardiologist, professor Dr Jovan Kosutic, from Institute for Mother and Child, where Tijana is being cured for six years, and at the moment our daughter is in the state of clinically poor condition, and the crucial factor in this case is time, and Tijana does not have it.

If Tijana’s departure to clinic to Houston is prolonged due to lack of money, it can happen that a permanent cancellation of other organs happens (kidneys, liver, lungs), which at the moment suffer the most because of weakend cardiac function, and then heart transplantation will not be possible.

We would like to inform You that action for help to Tijana is continued and that we still count on You and Your support which will in forthcoming period be very much needed. We believe that together we will collect missing money assets and to make possible for Tijana to set out to America for a new heart.

Having in mind everyday costs of treatment, such as high costs of the transplantation, please monetarily help according to Your possibilities to our daughter Tijana Ognjanovic.
story_txt:
LETTER FROM HER PARENTS
 
http://www.tijanaognjanovic.com/index-eng.html
Our daughter Tijana Ognjanovic, aged 8, urgently needs help for treatment abroad. Having in mind really serious health condition of the sick girl, who has been diagnosed with restrictive cardiomyopathy, medical council has suggested the transplatiton to be performed as soon as possible.
Having in mind that this kind of operation is not performed in our country, and Republic Institute for health insurance does not cover costs for operation and postoperative treatment of this kind of disease, left on our own, we initiated action for help to Tijana to get a new heart. For relatively short time with help of people of good will who have supported this humanitarian action, we have collected 200.000 EUR for heart transplatation and postoperative treatment in Vienna.
In January this year, we went to Vienna, to AKH clinic, where after detailed analysis they have informed us that clinic is not capable to put Tijana on waiting list and perform heart transplatation, because of complications which have appeared by the end of December 2012. (kidney failure) and very rare form of restrictive cardiomyopathy from which Tijana suffers. As Tijana has been classified in third risk group (there are three groups), they gave her only 2% chance to survive operation in their centre (we have enclosed conclusion of transplantation team from AKH clinic).
Faced with this facts and not wishing to give up, we were forced to find a clinic which has experience with this rare kind of restrictive cardiomyopathy and which would accept Tijana as high risk patient. We have contacted many cardiologists in the country and abroad and we have received data that clinics in America have most experience with this kind of cardiomyopathy, from which the child clinic in Houston has especially stood out. We have contacted them and got answer that in relatively short period we can get heart, but this kind of operation costs 1.015.000,00 $. (Here you can find enclosed breakdown of estimated charges.)
Having in mind report of Tijana’s cardiologist, professor Dr Jovan Kosutic, from Institute for Mother and Child, where Tijana is being cured for six years, and at the moment our daughter is in the state of clinically poor condition, and the crucial factor in this case is time, and Tijana does not have it.
If Tijana’s departure to clinic to Houston is prolonged due to lack of money, it can happen that a permanent cancellation of other organs happens (kidneys, liver, lungs), which at the moment suffer the most because of weakend cardiac function, and then heart transplantation will not be possible.
We would like to inform You that action for help to Tijana is continued and that we still count on You and Your support which will in forthcoming period be very much needed. We believe that together we will collect missing money assets and to make possible for Tijana to set out to America for a new heart.
Having in mind everyday costs of treatment, such as high costs of the transplantation, please monetarily help according to Your possibilities to our daughter Tijana Ognjanovic.

story:
Fight for Giovanni

My name is Cheryl di Leonardo. Giovanni's father died of colon cancer when Giovanni was 16 months old so we are on our own for this journey. My 7 year old son contracted Lyme disease as a small baby that the dogs brought in from the field. the doctors could'nt diagnose him until he was 3 years old with such a late diagnosis the disease caused severe damage to his optical nerves and central nervous system. We had to get very aggressive with treaments to kill the Lyme bacteria and had to put him on extreamly high doses of antbiotic for 4 years to get rid of it , i had to also put him on high doses of probiotic to replace the good bacteria in his stomach that the antibiotic killed, it caused his baby teeth to turn brown but had to do this to kill this very hard to get rid of Lyme disease, the Lyme caused Giovanni to go almost completly blind and caused cerebral palsy and autistic characteristics. He cannot talk yet , walks with a sever limp and cannot run. After extensive research, i know stem cell transfusion is the only way to help my son to correct the scare tissue damage Lyme caused him,these treatment are only in the research stage in the U.S and will take many years to be approved here, and will be very costly when we do get it, many countries do this now Giovanni's case has been accepted for stem cell transfusions at Shenzen Beike Hospitols in China for Sep.- Oct. 2013 for 30 days of treatment, the Doctors will be using umbilical cord stem cells plus rehabilitation therapies everyday-accupuncture, phyical therapy, pressure point massage and more. All of these treatment will give my little boy the best chance to live a normal life. I am happy to say we have raised $10,000.00 through a fund raiser dinner i put on but time is running close to our approved date and may have to pospone our trip till a later date,and fly in the bad weather, i will continue this journey until we can raise the funds to get him there. Thank you so much for listening to his story and for anything you can do to help us, sincerly Giovanni's mom

 

 

 

 .

story:
Veronica

My sister-in-law, Veronica, was diagnosed with late Stage 2 Lyme Disease and Endometriosis. That, along with a weakened immune system, a household mold problem, and continual health issues has caused my brother (Neil) and Veronica numerous medical bills and, on top of that, constant frustration. My family is throwing her a Benefit in Fergus Falls, MN on April 19, 2013 but I wanted to create a way for you to support Veronica, even if you can't physically attend the Benefit. 

The Diagnosis

The last few months have been increasingly difficult for my family as Veronica has had her gallbladder removed and had surgery in both her abdomen and right thoracic cavity for adhesions and scar tissue. Her liver is no longer doing well, due to all the stress, which means her body is unable to detox--causing her heart to race. As a result, Veronica is now on a liquid/soup diet, in an attempt to restore her liver since it cannot process food or vitamins any longer.

The Old Fashioned Way

Since all the funds raised from this campaign will go directly to Veronica's medical bills, I decided to opt out of the "perks" option. Maybe it's a little old fashioned--donating while expecting nothing in return--but "old fashioned" is how we do it in rural MN! (Which is why the "Hollywood Girl" is creating this online campaign!)

I'm grateful that this community has taught me the importance of relying on one another and bearing each other's burdens--every word of encouragement, prayer, and small donation will go a long way! Thanks for being a part of my life and caring for my family (even if you've never met them).

Hope For The Future

I believe in hope and I believe in a future for Veronica. So many of you have been lifting Veronica up in prayer and I couldn't be more thankful. I believe there is healing available if it's in God's plan. Please consider contributing financially or keep lifting Veronica up in prayer. I do believe that God yearns for us to pray and wants that relationship with each and every one of us--I would be honored if you would join with me in this hope.

Thanks to you all! Please pass this along to help us reach our campaign goal!

 

Shanna

story:
This donation page was set up orginally to find a cure for beloved friend and mother, Sue Walz, who was diagnosed with ALS Jan '12.

Sue was an incredible woman, full of life. Unfortunately in Jan '11, she started noticing symptoms of the devastating disease ALS, aka Lou Gehrig's Disease. Sue passed away in her sleep on the afternoon of July, 11th, 2013.

I want to thank everyone who donated money to help Sue try and find a cure, she died feeling so much love and hope. 

As for the donations, I will be in touch with everyone who has donated up to now and ask them what they wish to do. The plan then is to leave the donation site open, with the money now going towards her funeral service. Anything above and beyond that will go directly towards the ALS Assosiation of Sacramento, without whom we wouldn't have the wheelchair that made it possible for her to go to blues shows and festivals in her last few months, not to mention in inumberable other things that they provided us to make her life so much better.

I will be certain to keep everyone informed about funeral services over on the FaceBook page; facebook.com/RestInPeaceSueWalz

For more info on ALS, follow the link below:

http://www.alsa.org/about-als/what-is-als.html

For info on the Sac chapter of the ALSA where all extra donations will go:

http://websac.alsa.org/

story:
My name is Mike. I am a husband and a father of two. I am here to ask for your help in getting a gastric sleeve operation. I have been denied by my insurance company at every step of my weight loss journey. They refuse to cover any dietary programs.

My Story

I was born with the worst case of congenital bilateral clubfeet seen in 1973. According to doctors I would never walk. But that news did not discourage my parents and I had my first of 14 surgeries at just 18 hours old. By the time I was three months old both of my legs were in heavy casts. At five years of age I had been through a total of 10 bone repositioning surgeries. To everyone’s surprise I took my first unsteady steps at the age of five. I have undergone every type of bone correction available, had pins, worn braces and shoe supports just to get where I am today. My most recent reconstructive surgery was in 2002.

My life has been severely impacted by my disability. Starting in childhood, my feet and legs held me back from playing as a normal child. I spent a great portion of that time recovering from more corrective surgeries. The muscles in my calves and ankles had begun to atrophy. My weight began to increase in early childhood and my obesity battle began.

In 6th grade I weighed 200 pounds and was diagnosed with high blood pressure. By graduation I was topping 300 pounds and my blood pressure was still a major issue. Recently I was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and it was discovered that I have an enlarged heart. As of today I take five medications to control my blood pressure and three for my diabetes.

I have daily pain in my feet, ankles and knees. Pain that I know would be alleviated if I was able to lose this excess weight. My father passed away when I was 18 years old. I do not want to do that to my girls or wife. My goal is to be in this world longer than he was…to celebrate several more birthdays with them.

What We Need & What You Get

I have found a hospital that will perform the surgery for approximately $6,000.  This covers the surgery and post-op care. As this is not a local hospital, this does not include transportation for me or my wife to the surgery location or accommodations for her while I am under their care.

We are also interested in clinics or doctors willing to donate their services.

We have several tiers of donation possibilities thanks to contributions from our community.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you for taking the time to read my story. I appreciate any and all monetary support you're able to provide; however, I understand that many of you are unable to contribute financially to my campaign. Regardless, I would appreciate your help in spreading the word about our project! You can like my page, Help Me Lose at https://www.facebook.com/HelpMeLose, on Facebook or follow us on Twitter at HelpMeLose6252. You can also help by spreading the link to this Indiegogo page in a status update or tweet.

 

A Letter From Mike

I want folks to understand something.  Believe it or not me wanting this surgery for my health is only a small portion.  I figure that I am here in this world and unlike some I want to be productive.  And on any given day I don't make it past 8 pm.  Weekends I barely remember due to the fatigue and drain not to mention leg,ankle, knee, feet and hip pain that they can't prescribe me a dosage that touches it.  But with all this my main reason to stick around is my friends and family.  Not that I feel I am important you see.... but some of you do.  And one thing that hurts me most is to see others hurt cause of me.  Since I was a teen I always have felt I was out here to listen, fix, help, teach and even protect from others and themselves.  So I just wanted you who may read this know that whatever help you give will not be wasted.  I will do my damndest to continue being who I am and make the change count and last.  Thank you for your time...  FITZ

A Letter From A Childhood Friend

Mike you have been an inspiration to me my whole journey in this thing called life. For you that don't know Mike and I were best friends in our child hood day's. From the time we could speak and maybe before. I saw your hard times and was there for the bulling that you took. But Mikey from the bottom of my Soul you are and your experiences have made me into the person I have become. Just like our Journey's we would go on together as  children I am on the ship with you now. I was there when you came home surgery after surgery and they said you would never walk but together I remember us running a few times. Never and I repeat Never hit a bird house with a bat you never know what is inside. I am going to share this page and help every way I can your Friend and brother.

story:
This fund-raiser is to assist my big brother, Daniel, with his treatment in his fight against cancer. He is 31 years-old and has cancer of the parotid gland which is a type of salivary gland cancer. He has already underwent extensive surgery to remove the tumor that was wrapped within the main facial nerve near his right ear. He is now going through radiation therapy everyday for the next six weeks. The treatment has made it impossible for him to work in his job as a field biologist with the University of Florida. This loss of work has made it especially difficult financially because he has no paid sick days. Daniel and his wife are under constant strain to make ends meet and this fund is an attempt to ease some of the burden on he and his family.

We are casting a wide net attempting to get a large amount of small donations. Little ripples can make big waves! Please give what you can and keep Daniel and his family in your thoughts and prayers!

Thank you for your kind and generous support.
