story:
My name is Michael and Justin is my partner. Justin was recently diagnosed with avascular necrosis and is now unable to work and he does not have insurance. He requires two surgeries, a bone graft on his left hip and a hip replacement on his right hip. I am trying to help, but on a nonprofit salary we are sinking fast. With your donations we will be able to help Justin pay for his surgeries and associated medical bills.

So far Justin has had two MRIs which total $3,000. He had a three day stay in the hospital which we have yet to receive the bill for; however since he is uninsured we can be sure it won't be cheap. The hip replacement surgery is estimated at around $50,000 but we don't have a final actual total for the surgery. We are only asking for a small portion of what our total bills will be. We need money to get the ball rolling and we work hard to figure out the rest as we go. Hopefully after the surgeries Justin will be able to work again and we will be in a better position to pay the medical bills.

Your contributions will allow us to pay for a portion of Justin's surgeries and give us the opportunity to get back on our feet, so to speak, and stay afloat while dealing with this difficult time. We're not asking for your bones, just your generous contributions.

Even if you are unable to contribute to our cause you may be able to spread the word so others may make contributions!

story:
BORIS GERUS

is an internationally-acclaimed and award-winning essayist, poet, musicologist, scholar, and translator of Polish, Hebrew, Russian, Ukrainian and Belorussian literature. He's widely published in Israel and has translated works by important authors such as Marek Krajewski, Jacek Dehnel, Julian Tuwim, Adam Zagajewski and Ewa Lipska and as such has helped bridge together Polish and Israeli cultures, among others. An Israeli of Polish origins, he currently resides in Warsaw, Poland.

 

HE NEEDS YOUR HELP


because he suffers from a rare, chronic, and fatal illness of the blood vessels known as Takayasu's Disease. This disease causes a serious disturbance to the body's blood circulation, especially to the limbs and internal organs, and can lead to amputation of the limbs, loss of eyesight, and in its final stage, death by stroke or brain hemmorrhage. Takayasu's is also physically painful, causing arm and leg weakness or pain with use. Over a year ago, Gerus took a turn for the worse, and he is no longer able to walk; he has also had trouble with his kidneys and heart, as well as diabetes. He finds himself living away from his family because doctors informed him the climate in Europe is better for his illness:

“I live in Warsaw by necessity, not because I deal with Polish culture,” he says. “I am completely alone. I have no family. I need all the help I can get. I find myself in a situation of total helplessness. Most of the time I’m unable to leave the house” (Ha'aretz).

 

THE MEDICAL COSTS


associated with Takayasu's are enormous at over $3,000 per month. This figure includes Gerus's medical care, medication, and in-home assistance. It allows his illness to be stabilized and prolongs his life such that he can carry out his important work that has seen no equal in Israel and the world.

 

WHAT YOUR HELP MEANS


beyond easing the symptoms and extending Gerus's life, your donation benefits first-rate cultural, artistic, and scholarly endeavors. It is especially important with regard to strained Polish-Jewish cultural connections.

Gerus writes: "The initiative, addressed to all people of good will, does not only consist in activity in my own favour, but represents a contribution to the development of Polish and Jewish culture and to its popularization outside Poland, which is not without an impact on Jewish culture either."

Any monetary donation you make or help you can offer (e.g., spreading awareness through social media) is an affirmation of life and the importance of humanistic endeavors.

 

FOR MORE INFORMATION


On Boris:

  • http://www.haaretz.com/news/features/a-very-frail-bridge-between-polish-and-hebrew-cultures.premium-1.502472
  • http://peacenikhurler.blogspot.com/2013/02/a-polish-translator-to-treasure-boris.html

On Takayasu's DIsease:

  • http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/takayasus-arteritis/DS00832

It allows his illness to be stabilized and prolongs his life such that he can carry out his important work that has seen no equal in Israel and the world.

beyond easing the symptoms and extending Gerus's life, your donation benefits first-rate cultural, artistic, and scholarly endeavors. It is especially important with regard to strained Polish-Jewish cultural connections.
Gerus writes: "The initiative, addressed to all people of good will, does not only consist in activity in my own favour, but represents a contribution to the development of Polish and Jewish culture and to its popularization outside Poland, which is not without an impact on Jewish culture either."
Any monetary donation you make or help you can offer (e.g., spreading awareness through social media) is an affirmation of life and the importance of humanistic endeavors.
 
FOR MORE INFORMATION
On Boris:


http://www.haaretz.com/news/features/a-very-frail-bridge-between-polish-and-hebrew-cultures.premium-1.502472 

http://peacenikhurler.blogspot.com/2013/02/a-polish-translator-to-treasure-boris.html
On Takayasu's DIsease:

http://www.mayoclinic.com/health/takayasus-arteritis/DS00832

story:
Short Summary

Imagine having to walk a great distance to get water for your family of five. Then imagine getting there and having to decide if you or your neighbors are the lucky ones to get water for the next four days--the same water which will feed and bathe your family and crops.

Water is arguably the most important natural resource to sustain life. Of all the planet's renewable resources, water may be the most unforgiving. Difficult to purify, expensive to transport, and impossible to substitute, water is essential to public health and sanitation, food production, to economic development, and to sustain life itself. 

Here in India, the water shortage is noticable as you walk through the slums and see families lined up with their empty buckets. The visceral fear shows in the eyes of the community when they have to decide which families get water for the next 4 days, and which don't. Those who don't get it have to pay excessive amounts of their precious money stores, walk or bike for a few hours daily (taking them away from income-earning opportunities or putting them at risk for health and safety problems), or go without.

What We Need & What You Get

Last year, HELP International's India team helped construct a single bore well in one Hyderabad slum to provide access to clean water. Through our partner, SAPID, who has worked in the slums for over 7 years, we have identified 5 more slums who need bore wells. When all 5 are constructed, over 6,000 individiuals will have access to clean water.

These families, most of whom don't make more than $50 a month, have decided that this is their first priority and have started gathering funds to provide a well for themselves. In fact, they have raised more than half of the costs to provide for the entire cost of: 

  • the pump/motor
  • the construction of the tank
  • necessary piping and electrical connections

All we are going to do on our end is provide for the drilling of the 5 bore wells (total of $4,500 for all 5), and the community will provide the rest.

We have already had a geologist survey and identify the most successful locations for drilling of water. Our partner, SAPID, has already negotiated good prices through the drilling company if we can do all 5 on consecutive days. All we have left to do is raise the funds for our portion of the bore well.

The Impact

This is more than just building 5 bore wells in Hyderabad slums. Last year's bore well has brought the community together to work in unity. They have created and appointed a bore well committee that takes care of their equipment and precious stores of water. They have learned that if they work together, they can pool together money for the greater good of the community. This project is empowering, and sustainable.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help. We would ask that you help spread the word. Please share:

  • This page: http://www.indiegogo.com/borewells 
  • Our team blog: http://india.help-international.org/
  • Our team Tumblr: http://helpindia.tumblr.com/

Thank you!!

story:
My Story

My name is Amy Hildreth, I am A 27 year old photographer from Boston. In 2008 I was diagnosed with Lyme Disease, as a result of poor diagnostics and a heavy dose of antibiotics, my teeth began to deteriorate from the inside out. When i was just 23 years old, i had my first 4 teeth pulled. From there it became almost bi monthly that i was having a tooth pulled or some sort of procedure to try to stop the pain of having my teeth fall out. I am currently in the middle of having full implants, procedures that included, bone grafting, sinus lift, metal posts implanted into my lower jaw and having dentures made. All of this already costing somewhere around $25,000. I need almost another $40,000 to finish this whole thing. As you can imagine this is a huge undertaking and my father, the hero that he is, has done everything he can up to this point to make sure this horrible time in my life has gone as smoothly as possible. We are unfortunately at the point where we can't do it alone and I am now here to ask for your help.

The Impact

All the money you donate will go immediately to help me have my next surgery, having 8 metal posts implanted into my top jaw, as well as helping me FINALLY getting my implants! It has been a very long time since i could bite into an apple, eat steak or have a sandwich. Without help, it will be years until i can finally put this behind me. 

What We Need & What You Get

I am asking for $38,000, this is the quote they have given me to have this whole thing finished. The next surgery is going to cost at least $9,000. A procedure that i am hoping to have done before the summer kicks in so i can actually enjoy this summer unlike the past 3! I am not asking for big donations from a few people, i am only hoping for small donations from everyone. Every single dollar helps me to get closer to having my smile back!

story:
American men have a 1 in 2 chance of getting cancer, and American women a 1 in 3 chance in their lifetime and there is only a 50% chance of cure across all cancers. Due to the increased funding for heart disease and AIDS and limited funding for cancer research, cancer is now the number one killer in the US. Close to 1600 Americans die of cancer every day which equates to approximately one Twin Tower going down every day.

Through the Team in Training (TNT) program, the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society (LLS) has raised over $1.2 billion which has led to the production and funding of 19 of the 30 new FDA cancer drugs approved by the FDA since 2002. Other cancer patients have also benefited from these research findings. This is arguably more funding than our US government has provided, especially in recent years.

I have a mission-to help find cures and more effective treatments for blood cancers. To accomplish that mission, I’m participating in my 1st FULL IRONMAN race (2.4mi swim, 112mi bike ride and 26.2mi marathon run) in Coeur d'alene Idaho June 23rd, 2013 as a member of The Leukemia and Lymphoma Society’s (LLS) Team In Training. Like the other members of TNT, I will be raising funds to help find cures and better treatments for leukemia, lymphoma, Hodgkin’s disease and myeloma. I’m improving the quality of my life by participating and with your support, I can help improve the quality of life for patients and their families as well.

Please make a donation in support of my efforts with Team In Training and help advance the research for cures. If I do not reach my goal I will not be allowed to participate in the race!

 

Go Team,

PJ

story:
HELLO EVERYONE,

My name is Sandra Tran and on January 2nd, 2017 I found out that I have been selected to represent for Team USA at the International Powerlifting Federation World Championships in Minsk, Belarus. I will be leaving June 14th, 2017. I want to thank everyone that has been by my side since day one. Thank you for the unconditional love and supports that got me this far. Without the support that I have, I would not be where I am today.

My top goal in powerlifting was to qualified to compete at the highest level. Which is going to worlds and representing for the best country in the world. I now have the chance to do so. I will be aiming at my highest potential that I have to make my country proud and being the best in my weight class.

Any contribution would be greatly appreciated! THANK YOU FOR YOUR TIME!
